persona.name: Marilyn Josephine Peterson

occupation.title: Retired Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA); part-time caregiver and child caregiver
occupation.organization: Retired from St. Croix Community Nursing Home (30+ years). Now does occasional shifts as a substitute caregiver at a local assisted-living facility and provides primary in-home care for the two young children under her guardianship.
occupation.description: Marilyn worked for three decades as a CNA in long-term care. Her responsibilities included personal care (bathing, dressing), medication reminders (not administering controlled meds), wound checks, and supporting dementia residents with routines and meals. She trained new aides informally, knows how to chart basic care, and is skilled in calming distressed residents. Since retiring from full-time work five years ago she has worked occasional shifts to supplement income, does regular babysitting and daytime caregiving for the toddlers in her household, and provides neighborhood meal prep and light housekeeping for an elderly neighbor for a modest fee. Her caregiving skill set includes basic first aid, CPR (certification lapsed but she refreshes periodically), feeding special-needs toddlers, and managing daily schedules for children and adults with mobility challenges. She is comfortable with traditional, practical caregiving and prefers hands-on work to desk jobs.

persona.residence: Small suburb outside Minneapolis, Minnesota, United States
persona.education: Attended community college (Anoka-Ramsey Community College). Completed a 10-month Certified Nursing Assistant (CNA) certificate and several continuing-education courses in eldercare and child first aid. High-school diploma from a suburban public high school. Took occasional non-credit classes later in life (basic computer skills, quilting).
long_term_goals: Provide a stable, loving home for the two young children (ages 4 and 2) she is legally raising and ensure they have access to preschool and health care.
Remain independent in her own home as long as possible while managing chronic health issues.
Leave a small but secure legacy (savings + paid-off house) to the children when she dies.
Stay civically involved in her local church and community center and continue volunteering with the neighborhood senior group.
Keep her physical mobility steady enough to play in the yard and take short family outings.
Learn to use video-calling well enough to keep distant family connected and to show the kids grandparents who live far away.
Pass on family recipes and holiday traditions rooted in Northern/Central European ancestry (pot roast at Christmas, lefse-like potato traditions adapted for a Midwestern kitchen).
persona.style: Warm, pragmatic, and plainspoken. Speaks with a soft Midwestern cadence (Minnesota-influenced, slight vowel rounding) and uses family-company idioms: "oh, you bet," "ain't that a thing," "we'll figure it out." Her tone is calm and maternal; she often speaks slowly when explaining something to children or newcomers. Uses humor that is self-deprecating and gentle teasing. Tends to repeat key points to make sure the listener understands (a habit from caregiving). Prefers practical clothing (printed cotton dresses, cardigans, sturdy shoes), minimal jewelry, and a small cross necklace. Mannerisms: smoothing her hands over clothing when nervous, making frequent eye contact with children, humming hymns under her breath, tapping one knee rhythmically when waiting, reaching out to touch a child's shoulder to reassure them. In conversation she names family members early and uses concrete examples; when upset she sighs audibly and withdraws to do chores. Comfortable using a landline and a basic smartphone (texting and the camera), but avoids social media beyond a private Facebook group used to share pictures with family.

traits: Deeply nurturing and patient with small children and older adults.
Pragmatic and resourceful—good at finding low-cost practical solutions.
Loyal and steady; values routines and obligations.
Cautious with finances and skeptical of quick schemes or high-pressure sales.
Traditionally minded about family roles but adaptable when circumstances demand.
Emotionally warm but guarded about private worries (doesn't overshare).
Sociable at community gatherings but prefers small groups over large parties.
Stubborn about certain preferences (food, routines), flexible about others.
Empathetic listener; remembers small personal details about neighbors and friends.
Occasionally worried about health and finances — can become anxious late at night.
Has a dry, ironic sense of humor that surfaces once comfortable.
Assertive when advocating for the children's needs at school or with medical providers.

big_five.openness: 3/10 — prefers familiar routines, music, books, and pastimes; curious about practical innovations (new child safety gear) but not experimental.
big_five.conscientiousness: 8/10 — very organized around household tasks, medication schedules, appointments and budgeting; punctual with commitments.
big_five.extraversion: 5/10 — enjoys small-group socializing (church circle, quilting group) and is friendly with neighbors, but needs downtime alone.
big_five.agreeableness: 8/10 — cooperative, trusting of neighbors and friends, willing to help; can be firm when protecting family interests.
big_five.neuroticism: 6/10 — generally stable but has worry-prone moments about health, money, and children's futures.

interests: Family-centered activities: backyard picnics, puppet shows for toddlers, bedtime story rituals.
Simple baking and cooking: making bulk soups, cinnamon rolls, apple pies adapted from Northern European traditions.
Quilting and hand-sewing: mending kids' clothes, making simple baby blankets.
Gardening: raised vegetable beds (potatoes, carrots, lettuces) and container herbs on the porch.
Community volunteer work: church meals program, senior center bingo helper, PTA support.
Listening to oldies (1960s-1970s), church hymns, and radio morning shows while doing chores.
Watching public television children's programs and occasional classic family films.
Reading practical how-to books (parenting, budgeting, first-aid), light novels, and a daily paper.
Collecting family photographs and maintaining a physical photo album.
Simple crafts with kids: finger painting, salt dough ornaments, paper snowflakes.
Walking local parks with a stroller or toddler harness, birdwatching for small backyard species.
Neighborhood swap meets and garage sales—likes the hunt for bargains and practical finds.
Knit-along groups at the library where she helps younger parents learn to sew buttons back on clothes.
Basic digital skills: using a smartphone camera, voice calls, video calls with out-of-state relatives.
Prefers in-person gatherings to screen-based socialization for close friends and family.
Gardening catalogs and church newsletters are a regular delight.
Comfortable with printed lists and paper calendars (keeps a big wall calendar with appointments).
Prefers supportive, incremental advice rather than aggressive or rapid change suggestions.
Likes quiet mornings with tea and the newspaper before the household wakes up.
Values intergenerational activities where older adults and children interact (storytime sessions at the library).
likes: Family meals cooked from scratch—stews, casseroles, roasted vegetables.
Children's handmade gifts and earnest scribbled drawings.
Secondhand stores where she can find children's clothes in good shape.
Simple, sturdy toys (wooden blocks, picture books, push toys).
Warm, plain coffee in the morning (often medium roast with a splash of milk).
A tidy, functional kitchen and well-organized pantry.
Holiday traditions: decorated tree, simple Advent rituals, baking on the weekend.
A slow, predictable travel pace rather than packed itineraries.
Quiet, shaded picnic spots near a playground where children can play safely.
Cars with easy-to-latch child seats and large trunk space for a stroller.
Practical footwear: non-slip soles and supportive insoles for long days on her feet.
Houseplants that are forgiving and cheap to replace if a child spills water.
Discount coupons and loyalty cards—saves them carefully.
Neighbors who look out for one another and exchange keys for emergencies.
Simple board games and memory games she can play with kids and visiting grandchildren.
Affordable, durable clothing that can survive messy toddler days.
Local eateries that offer kids' portions and quick service.
dislikes: Noisy, crowded tourist traps that are hard with toddlers.
Expensive, luxury-heavy vacation resorts with little kid programming aimed at high-spend clientele.
Gimmicky baby gadgets that break quickly or are hard to clean.
People who dismiss older caregivers as incapable or uninterested in child-rearing.
Complex technology that requires frequent updates or subscriptions.
Pressure to move the children into expensive private programs she cannot afford.
Fast-talking salespeople and high-pressure financing plans.
Unreliable public transportation when traveling with small kids.
Pushy parenting advice that shames choices made for practicality.
Food fads that replace family-favorite simple meals.
vacation_preferences: Prefers short drives (2-4 hours) to reduce stress with young children rather than air travel.
Values destinations with safe, family-friendly accommodation (ground-floor rooms, crib availability).
Chooses vacation spots with predictable routines—consistent mealtimes, nap-friendly schedules.
Likes rented cottages or small family suites with a kitchenette to prepare simple meals for picky toddlers.
Gravitates toward quiet lakeside cabins, state parks with cabin rentals, or small coastal towns with calm beaches.
Prioritizes child safety: fenced yards, lifeguarded beaches, clear walking routes, shaded play areas.
Brings a stash of favorite toys, a folding travel high chair, and a lightweight travel stroller to maintain routines.
Schedules travel during off-peak seasons to get better rates and fewer crowds.
Avoids long museum visits and packed itineraries; prefers parks, short nature trails, and playground stops.
Looks for nearby medical clinics or urgent care centers at the destination—maps these before arrival.
Enjoys short boat rides or ferry trips if they are calm and quick (10–30 minutes) rather than long cruises.
Prefers family-friendly state parks with easy interpretive trails and picnic shelters.
Chooses accommodations that provide laundry facilities to cope with toddler spills and frequent changes.
Brings baker's ingredients and plans a simple bake (cookies or muffins) as a calming family ritual on trips.
Wants lodging with an enclosed outdoor area so the kids can play safely while adults supervise.
Likes destinations with simple local attractions (farm visits, petting zoos, small aquariums) that entertain young kids.
Schedules one restful day mid-trip to recalibrate and avoid overtiring the children.
Avoids destinations requiring a lot of transfers or flights, preferring direct driving routes to minimize meltdowns.
Prefers places with local grocery stores nearby rather than all-inclusive dining that might not fit toddlers' tastes.
Chooses destinations where her husband can do light fishing or quiet walks while she watches the children.
Brings a basic first-aid kit and favorite comfort blanket or stuffed toy for each child to reduce travel anxiety.
Likes to keep phone numbers of close relatives and local emergency services printed and handy.
Prefers to book refundable or low-penalty reservations when possible due to health and family unpredictability.
Values small-town charm and friendly shopkeepers who accommodate small children.
Avoids highly urban destinations with limited outdoor play space.
Enjoys simple guided activities that are short (30–60 minutes) and child-appropriate (petting zoo, short train ride).
Prefers to travel with another adult (a cousin or an aunt) who can help with the children occasionally.
Likes to include an intergenerational relative (a younger adult child or a cousin) to help hold and entertain the toddler, making outings feasible.
Brings a foldable play-pen for safe indoor play and a small bath thermometer to check bathwater at unfamiliar places.
Makes a simple 'vacation checklist' laminated and kept in her purse: medications, children's snacks, wipes, spare clothes, night-light, book, camera, and insurance cards.
Avoids late-night activities; bedtime remains a priority even on vacation so the children remain predictable.
shopping_and_consumption: Prefers discount grocers and buys in bulk when feasible for staples (flour, canned goods, diapers when on sale).
Buys secondhand children's clothing but prefers new shoes and car seats for safety reasons.
Uses coupons, local flyers, and takes advantage of senior discounts when available.
Prefers brands she has used for years; skeptical of new brands unless recommended by friends.
Buys simple, easy-to-clean toys and household items that survive repeated use and toddler spills.
food_preferences: Likes hearty Midwestern comfort foods: pot roast, mashed potatoes, split-pea soup, stewed apples.
Makes oatmeal every morning for herself and porridge-like foods for toddlers when needed.
Keeps snacks simple: cheese sticks, bananas, plain crackers, applesauce pouches for the kids.
Avoids heavily processed ready meals except in emergencies; prefers homemade with occasional convenience items.

beliefs: Family is the foundation of a good life; children need stability and predictable routines.
Older adults can and should be active contributors to child-rearing when families need help.
Neighbors should look out for one another; community matters more than flashy lifestyles.
Voting is a civic duty; she votes in nearly every local and national election.
Church and community groups provide moral support even if personal religiosity varies.
Hard work and thriftiness provide more reliable security than risky investments.
Medical professionals should be listened to but families should also ask questions and advocate for loved ones.
Affordable, accessible childcare is essential for working families and for grandparents assisting in caregiving.
Children learn best by example—honesty, patience, and chores taught early build character.
Government programs (like Medicaid or SNAP) are important safety nets for low-income seniors and families.
Public libraries are invaluable community resources for children’s development and low-cost entertainment.
People are generally well-intentioned; give others the benefit of the doubt but be cautious with strangers.
Traditions and holiday rituals help children feel rooted and connected to their ancestry.
Younger parents today face different pressures—technology, social media—be empathetic rather than judgmental.
Sensible budgeting and saving, even small amounts, provide peace of mind in retirement.
Respect for elders and intergenerational relationships should be fostered but not romanticized—older caregivers need help too.
Local politics often affects daily life (zoning, school schedules, transit) more than national issues.
Simple pleasures—good food, a warm bed, a reliable car—are underrated sources of well-being.
High-cost childcare without commensurate quality is exploitative and unsustainable.
Healthcare should be accessible and transparent; surprise medical bills are unjust and harmful.
Schools should emphasize basic skills and social-emotional learning; discipline with kindness is better than harsh punishment.
Practical skills (cooking, sewing, basic vehicle maintenance) are valuable life skills often neglected in modern schooling.
Older workers deserve respectful treatment; age discrimination in hiring is real and unfair.
People's religious beliefs vary, and that's okay—what matters is kindness and community support.
Technology is useful but should not replace face-to-face family time, especially for young children.
Children's exposure to nature and outdoor play is important for physical and mental development.
Debt is stressful; avoid taking on loans for non-essential items.
Charity should be local when possible because community members usually understand immediate needs best.
Simple pleasures and rituals can be a form of resilience during hard times.
It's important to teach children about personal safety without instilling fear—practical safety skills are empowering.
Recycling and small environmental habits are worthwhile, though she is skeptical of complicated green consumer choices.
People's political views are complex; relationships are more important than ideological purity.
Being dependable—showing up for school pick-ups, doctor appointments—matters more than grand gestures.
Healthcare and child services should be designed to accommodate working and caregiving families—not just those with expensive choices.
It's reasonable to be cautious about new, untested parenting 'fads'; evidence-based, common-sense approaches are best.
skills: Certified Nursing Assistant skills: bathing, dressing, safe transfers (with assistance), toileting assistance, observation and reporting of patient conditions.
Basic pediatric caregiving: preparing formula/child-appropriate meals, changing diapers, soothing techniques for colic, nap scheduling, reading aloud, and baby-proofing.
First aid and basic CPR (periodic refreshers). Comfortable treating minor cuts, fevers, and monitoring medications.
Household management: budgeting on a fixed income, doing laundry efficiently, mending clothes, grocery shopping on a tight budget.
Cooking from scratch and batch-cooking for freezing meals; adapting recipes for toddlers and picky eaters.
Gardening basics: planting, harvesting, simple pest control, and container gardening for limited space.
Organizational skills: appointment scheduling, keeping medical records and immunization cards, managing a paper calendar.
Low-tech problem solving: improvising child entertainment, fixing broken toys, jury-rigging baby gates.
Basic driving and safe car-seat installation, including use of LATCH systems and choosing appropriate restraints for a child's age/weight.
Comforting and communicating with older adults with dementia—using redirection, music, and routines.

general: Frequently hums old hymns or radio jingles while doing chores.
Keeps a visible paper calendar in the kitchen and updates it daily.
Has a habit of checking door locks and windows twice before bed.
Always carries a small pouch with band-aids, baby wipes, a pen, and a grocery list.
Saves jars, cardboard boxes, and fabric scraps for crafts and practical reuse.
Talks to the children using full sentences and encourages naming feelings early on.
Often offers treats (small cookies) to neighbors' dogs and remembers people's birthdays.
Responds quickly to neighbor requests for help (driving to a clinic, picking up prescriptions) when able.
Sips coffee slowly in the morning while reviewing the day's plan; rarely skips this ritual.
Prefers to settle disputes in the house with calm discussion and practical problem-solving.

morning: Wakes between 5:30 and 6:30 AM most days; makes coffee and checks the wall calendar.
Prepares a simple breakfast (oatmeal or toast) and sets up children's snacks for the day.
Does a quick walk around the yard to check on plants and the mailbox.
Gets children dressed, changes diapers if needed, and packs a small day-bag with essentials before heading to preschool drop-off or playgroup.
Calls her husband to coordinate the day's logistics (who will be home when, meal prep, appointments).
midday: If not on a caregiving shift, spends mornings at the library storytime, PTA meetings, or volunteering at the church kitchen.
Runs errands mid-morning: grocery pickup, post office, or pharmacy visits.
Uses midday to batch-cook or thaw prepared meals, and to keep the house tidy before children return.
afternoon: Handles preschool pick-up or welcomes children back from playgroups; supervises snack and quiet play.
Schedules a short nap or quiet time for the younger child; uses this time to read, pay bills, or rest.
Keeps a fixed 4:00 PM 'homework/quiet craft' session to build routine for the 4-year-old.
evening: Prepares a simple dinner, often including leftovers to stretch groceries.
Bath and bedtime routine starts early (6:30–7:30 PM): bath, pajamas, story, and a brief prayer or quiet reflection.
After kids are asleep, she and her husband review the next day's schedule, and she reads or watches a public television program.
Tends to sleep by 10:00–10:30 PM but sometimes wakes at night to check on the children.
weekend: Visits the local farmers' market for produce and conversation with neighbors.
Invites family or friends for Sunday lunch; rotates simple potluck dishes.
Works on small home projects (mending, painting trim) and yard maintenance.
Takes a longer drive to visit adult children who live in neighboring counties or to attend a community event.
Attends church on Sunday mornings and volunteers occasionally for the coffee hour.

health.general_overview: Chronic health conditions typical of older adults, managed with medication and lifestyle, plus some mobility limitations and hearing loss. Mental health is generally stable but with occasional anxiety around finances and caregiving stress.
diagnoses: Hypertension — diagnosed 12 years ago, on a thiazide diuretic and ACE inhibitor; generally controlled when she remembers medication.
Osteoarthritis in knees and hands — variable pain, uses a knee brace sometimes and topical analgesics.
Mild hearing loss — uses a basic behind-the-ear hearing aid in the right ear; left ear has better hearing.
Mild Type 2 diabetes risk factors (borderline HbA1c previously); tries to manage with diet and exercise; not on insulin.
History of a fall two years ago with no major injury but increased caution since then.
Occasional seasonal allergies; reacts to strong perfumes.
mobility_and_disability: Uses a cane intermittently on longer walks and for stability on stairs; can walk short distances unassisted.
Has difficulty kneeling and crouching due to knee pain; asks children to sit on chairs for dressing rather than being lifted.
Requires some household help for heavier lifting (moving furniture, carrying large loads of wood or big laundry baskets).
medications_and_allergies: Daily medications: lisinopril, low-dose aspirin, occasional ibuprofen for arthritis (used sparingly due to blood pressure concerns), topical analgesic.
Allergic to penicillin (rash as a young adult) — always reminds healthcare staff.
Keeps children's medications (children's acetaminophen) locked and labeled.
mental_health: Generally resilient and content, but experiences intermittent anxiety related to finances, caregiving demands, and health worries.
Has had brief periods of low mood after stressful family events (e.g., a major family illness) but no formal diagnosis of major depression.
Finds solace in routine, prayer/hymns, volunteer work, and social contact at church.
sensory_and_other: Vision corrected with reading glasses; cataract surgery on one eye five years ago improved sight but requires reading glasses.
Dental work done intermittently; one missing molar replaced with a partial denture years ago.
Tolerates vaccinations well and keeps up-to-date on flu shots and recommended vaccines.
Non-smoker (quit in her 30s) and drinks very little alcohol (occasionally a glass of wine at a family meal).
healthcare_access: Has Medicare primary coverage and a modest supplemental plan; uses community clinic services for low-cost dental or urgent care when possible.
Keeps emergency contacts and a list of allergies/meds in the kitchen and in her wallet.

relationships.name: Harold Peterson
relationships.description: Married for 44 years. Retired machinist who now enjoys woodworking and quiet mornings. Supportive and methodical; shares household chores but finds toddler energy tiring. He still drives to local errands on weekends. Co-guardian of the two young grandchildren and the emotional partner who prefers action over long discussions.

relationships.name: Lila (4) and Benji (2)
relationships.relation: Children in her care (biological grandchildren legally in guardianship)
relationships.description: Two young children under the age of 6 who live with Marilyn and Harold permanently after their daughter (their mother) faced addiction and loss and recently completed a court-ordered treatment program; Marilyn and Harold are their primary caregivers. Lila is chatty and loves drawing; Benji is a modestly picky eater but affectionate. Marilyn manages most day-to-day needs and medical appointments for them.

relationships.name: Doreen Peterson
relationships.description: Daughter has struggled with substance use in the past and is currently in supervised recovery with limited contact. Marilyn supports family contact but prioritizes the children's stability and safety; sees Doreen at supervised visitations when appropriate.

relationships.name: Tommy and Sue (neighbors)
relationships.description: Neighbors who check in regularly, pick up mail during snowstorms, and trade garden produce. They provide ad-hoc childcare when Marilyn attends medical appointments sometimes.

relationships.name: St. Olaf Lutheran Church women's group
relationships.description: Small circle of 6–8 women who meet weekly for sewing, coffee, prayer, and fundraising. Marilyn is an active member and often volunteers for community outreach events.

relationships.name: Former coworkers
relationships.description: A network of former CNAs and nurses she stays in touch with by phone for advice and occasional substitute shifts; they exchange tips about local caregiving job openings and senior resources.

relationships.name: Adult son (Paul)
relationships.description: Works out of state with irregular hours but calls weekly. Financially limited; helps when he can with occasional childcare funding and visits a few times a year to help with big repairs.

relationships.name: Neighborhood teenagers
relationships.description: Marilyn hires neighborhood teens for short babysitting stints and pays them a modest wage; she sees this as both practical help and community-building.

other_facts: Born and raised in a small Midwestern town to parents of Northern/Central European ancestry (grandparents from Norway and Germany).
Family traditions include a yearly holiday potluck and a summer berry-picking outing that she tries to recreate with the children.
Married Harold at 24 in the church where she still volunteers; their marriage weathered long financial tight spells and a job layoff in the 1990s.
She became a CNA after her youngest of three children was born and needed a flexible career to accommodate childcare.
Worked 30+ years at St. Croix Community Nursing Home; remembers residents' names long after they passed and still keeps an album of photos and notes.
Took a break from full-time work to help care for an ailing parent in her late 50s and developed a deeper appreciation for in-home caregiving.
Acquired her current house (3-bedroom bungalow) at age 48 with community-bank financing; the mortgage was paid off in recent years and that provides some security.
Has basic computer skills: manages email, digital photos, and occasional Zoom calls with extended family, but prefers phone calls and face-to-face visits for important matters.
Keeps an emergency binder with insurance numbers, birth certificates, the kids' immunization records, and a list of trusted phone numbers in a locked drawer.
Was a Girl Scout leader in the 1980s for a local troop and still appreciates the confidence-building activities she taught.
Has a small stash of homemade freezer meals for unexpected guests or busy days with toddlers.
Once took a solo bus trip to visit a sister in Wisconsin and values that memory of independence.
Participates in an annual neighborhood cleanup and helps organize the church's Thanksgiving meal program.
Remembers the names of dozens of residents from the nursing home and occasionally writes birthday cards to their families.
Is meticulous about vaccine records for the children and keeps printed copies in the kitchen drawer.
Has a faded recipe box of handwritten cards inherited from her mother and grandmother; uses them for holiday menus and to teach the children simple baking steps.
Keeps a 'yard of the month' noteboard where neighbors leave short notes and small treats (apple pie slices, jam) which she both gives and receives.
Had a minor car accident in her 50s that resulted in increased caution driving in winter conditions; buys winter tires and avoids long highway trips in bad weather.
Once fostered a litter of kittens for a local shelter; she still feeds neighborhood strays occasional scraps but believes in adopting responsibly.
A treasured memory: leading a community sing-along for seniors and children at the library—an intergenerational event she helped start.
Has a modest life insurance policy designated to the children and a small savings account that acts as an emergency fund.
Is protective about the children's screen time: allows short, supervised digital cartoons occasionally but prefers reading and outdoor play.
Collects postcards from each place she visits, even if it's a short county fair trip; the postcards decorate a hallway corkboard.
Keeps a small jar for 'loose change' that she uses for kids' birthday presents and small neighborhood gifts.
Values practical skills and often teaches the 4-year-old how to sort laundry, water plants, and fold napkins as a play activity.
Has a habit of writing short, encouraging notes and leaving them in lunch boxes or on the children's pillow on hard days.
Enjoys simple bird identification and keeps a small book near the kitchen window; she points out robins and cardinals to the children.
Has an old upright piano that she used to play as a teenager; she plays simple tunes to soothe the children at nap time.
Keeps a 'medical bag' by the front door with the children's medications, thermometer, and insurance cards when leaving the house.
Once took a free adult-education class on reading children's literature to better engage with preschool storytime.
Is involved in a neighborhood mutual-aid list and exchanges rides, quick childcare, and meals with half a dozen nearby households.
Remembers local election officials and signed up as a poll worker once out of civic pride but stopped because of health concerns; she still volunteers to hand out flyers for civic events.
Has a small wooden chest of keepsakes: a baby bracelet from each of her children, a ribbon from her wedding bouquet, and a stack of cards from the nursing-home residents thanking her for care.
Is an avid keeper of lists—grocery, medication refills, birthday dates, and a small 'to-do' list stuck to the fridge every morning.
When she was younger she played in a church choir and still hums the same harmonies when folding laundry.
She once participated in a home safety program and had grab bars installed in the bathroom; she now recommends such small modifications to friends.
Has been called to be a witness in a custody case as a community-respected caregiver once; that experience reinforced her belief in formalizing guardianship paperwork for the children's security.
